questions.text: Which of the following is a biomarker of alcoholic hepatitis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GGT GGT is a microsomal enzyme and its measurement provides a sensitive index to assess liver abnormality. It is highly elevated in biliary obstruction and alcoholism. Serum γ-glutamyl transferase (GGT) is the sensitive indicator of alcohol use. For chronic viral hepatitis and non-alcoholic fatty liver, AST: ALT ratio less than 1 For alcoholic liver disease, AST: ALT ratio >2:1 Lactate dehydrogenase isozyme-5 (LDH-5) is also a major diagnostic test for liver diseases

questions.text: During exercise, which is the most rapid way to synthesize ATP?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phosphocreatine We do not store a significant amount of ATP and need a continuous supply; it must be constantly resynthesized. This occurs in several ways using one of the three energy systems: – Phosphagen (immediate source) – Anaerobic (somewhat slow, uses carbohydrates) – Aerobic (slow, uses either carbohydrate or fat) Phosphagen This system uses creatine phosphate (CP) and has a very rapid rate of ATP production. The creatine phosphate is used to reconstitute ATP after it is broken down to release its energy. The total amount of CP and ATP stored in muscles is small, so there is limited energy available for muscular contraction. It is, however, instantaneously available and is essential at the onset of activity, as well as during short-term high-intensity activities lasting about 1–30 seconds in duration, such as sprinting, weight-lifting, or throwing a ball. Aerobic glycolysis has a slow rate of ATP production and is predominantly utilized during longer-duration, lower-intensity activities after the phosphagen and anaerobic systems have fatigued.

questions.text: In noncompetitive antagonism, which of the following is correct?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vmax decreases In noncompetitive inhibition, there is no structural resemblance with the substrate and the noncompetitive inhibitors bind to the enzyme at a different site, not at the active site. So Vmax decreases and Km is unchanged.

questions.text: There is a patient with type I diabetes mellitus and complains of polyuria. Which of the following will occur normally in his body?

options.label: C
options.text: Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl CoA

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl CoA
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl CoA Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl CoA > D. Decreased in cholesterol synthesis In type I DM, insulin is decreased or not produced. So lipolysis increases, leading to increased beta oxidation, increased production of acetyl CoA, and hence increased ketogenesis. Ketoacidosis is the most prominent feature of type 1 DM. Studies have revealed that in such cases cholesterol synthesis will be decreased. Decreased insulin levels cause fatty acid synthesis to decrease and glucagon levels to increase. As decreased insulin levels cause decreased acetyl CoA carboxylase activity, hence decreased production of malonyl CoA, an allosteric inhibitor of CPT-I the RLE of beta oxidation. So uninhibited beta oxidation, i.e., fatty acid conversion to acetyl CoA. Adipose triacylglycerol’s are degraded and fatty acids are released. They are converted to ketone bodies in the liver and ketoacidosis can occur. Non enzymatic decarboxylation of acetoacetate forms acetone, which causes the odor associated with diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: In a child with cerebrohepatorenal syndrome and with hypotonia and hepatomegaly, the probable biochemical defect is accumulation of:
questions.correct_answer: C. Very long chain fatty acids
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Very long chain fatty acids (VCLFAs) Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is also known as Zellweger syndrome, a rare congenital disorder. It is caused due to the reduction or absence of the peroxisomes in the cell. Peroxisomes are the site of oxidation of VCLFAs. Deficiency of peroxisomes leads to increased concentration of VLCFAs.

questions.text: Method of transport of glucose in the intestine is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Secondary active transport Secondary active transport is the transport of molecules across the cell membrane utilizing energy in other forms than ATP. This energy comes from the electrochemical gradient created by pumping ions out of the cell. This cotransport can be either via antiport or symport. Example: Na+/glucose co-transporter. The Na+ gradient created by the Na+/K+ ATPase is used by the Na+/Glucose co-transporter to transport glucose and Na+ back into the cell.
